content.question: Which of the following best explains how the bonding in a metal allows it to be ductile (i.e., allows it to be drawn into a wire)?

choices.label: Metal atoms are spherical; therefore, the solid metal can be easily drawn into wires that have a round cross-section.

Because of strongly directional bonding in the solid metal, the atoms both in front of and behind a given atom in a wire will bind together more strongly than the atoms not along the direction of the wire.
Because the mobile electrons attract the metal cations equally in all directions, the metal cations can move easily past one another as the metal is drawn into a wire.
Metal atoms tend to be much smaller than nonmetal atoms; therefore, they can move easily past one another as the metal is drawn into a wire.

content.answer: Because the mobile electrons attract the metal cations equally in all directions, the metal cations can move easily past one another as the metal is drawn into a wire.
